data.subject: JS
data.title: Paul: Life and Letters
data.description: The career and thought of the apostle Paul, at once a Jew, a Graeco-Roman, and a Christ believer, living within the Roman Empire. Attention is given to issues such as spirit, Jewish Law, grace, freedom and slavery, Christ, church, politics, gender and sexuality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Classical Hebrew 1
data.description: Biblical Hebrew for beginners. A study of the alphabet, and some of the basic vocabulary and grammar of the language.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors but not both. Taught at Laurier as NE 111.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Classical Hebrew 2
data.description: A continuation of RS 131/JS 105A. Most of the rules of grammar will be covered in this course and students will begin to read texts in the original language.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors but not both. Taught at Laurier as NE 112.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Relationships in the Bible (Old Testament)
data.description: Students will be introduced to the Hebrew Bible by way of selected readings which deal with a particular aspect of the human predicament. The focus will be on exploring relationships via narrative passages in the Old Testament and particularly in the Book of Genesis. The following relationships will be discussed: (a) Spousal (b) Human/God (c) Parent/child (d) Siblings (e) Gender issues in narratives of rape, incest, seduction and dominance.
data.notes: [Note: Knowledge of Hebrew is not required. This course fulfils an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors but not both.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Great Texts in the Jewish Tradition
data.description: This course will trace the development of biblical exegesis in the Jewish tradition. Interpretive methods and approaches to problems in the text such as redundancy, contradiction, and gaps will be surveyed, commencing with the Bible itself, through the classical period of the Talmud and concentrating on major medieval commentators. (The biblical episode of the 'Binding of Isaac' will be used as a paradigm to illustrate various approaches to the text.)
data.notes: [Note: Knowledge of Hebrew is not required. This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Power and Corruption in the Bible (Old Testament)
data.description: This course will deal with the period of the Prophets, e.g., Joshua, Kings, and Samuel. It will examine the uses and abuses of power analyzing the historical narratives and study the conflict between Saul and David, the political as well as the moral rise and fall of David.
data.notes: [Note: Knowledge of Hebrew is not required. This course fulfils an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors but not both.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: The Quest for Meaning in Modern Judaism
data.description: How does an ancient religious tradition remain relevant in the face of shifting cultural morals and beliefs and especially in light of the West's emphasis on relativism and freedom of choice? This course will explore the major themes and challenges that face Judaism and the Jewish people at the start of the 21st century. We will compare the insights of an extremely diverse group of Jewish thinkers on the place of tradition in the modern world, and examine the perpetual quest for meaning at the core of Judaism.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Jewish Responses to the Holocaust
data.description: The catastrophe and devastation of the Holocaust and the radical nature of its evil demanded responses within contemporary Jewish thought, identity, and experience. This course will explore philosophical, theological (Jewish law, rabbinic), literary (novels, poetry, memoirs, plays), and artistic (museums, memorials) attempts to deal with the issues the Holocaust raises.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: The Hebrew Prophets
data.description: A study of the biblical prophets with special attention to their religious experience, social critique, visions of the future, and the writings that bear their names.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors, but not both.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Jewish Philosophy
data.description: The course will explore the thought of various Jewish scholars throughout history on issues that were vital to their faith. The texts studied will be representative of the philosophical and rabbinic traditions on such matters as the nature of God, the problem of evil, creation, miracles, prophecy, and providence.
data.notes: [Note: Knowledge of Hebrew is not required. This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Kabbalah: Jewish Mysticism
data.description: This course will survey the roots, history, and symbolism of the Jewish mystical tradition known as Kabbalah. Students will be introduced to the major texts, charismatic mystical masters, and schools of Kabbalah, beginning with the ancient Rabbis through to contemporary exponents such as Hasidim and messianic groups. Particular attention will be focused on the Zohar (Book of Splendour) and popular appeals to the mystical tradition.
data.notes: [Note: Knowledge of Hebrew is not required. This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Visions of Israel in Judaism: From Biblical to Modern Times
data.description: This course surveys the significance of the land of Israel in Judaism from historical, textual, and religious perspectives. Topics covered include the politics of Ancient Israel, the concept of Israel in prayer and the rabbinic and medieval Jewish imagination, portrayals of Israel in Christian and Muslim texts, and the origins, visions, and challenges of Zionism and the modern State of Israel.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Judaism
data.description: An introduction to the religious tradition of the Jews, in terms of beliefs, practices, ideals, and institutions from the beginning to the present time.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: The Holocaust and Film
data.description: An examination of the Holocaust as portrayed in feature films and documentaries. Do cinematic attempts capture the horror of the Holocaust faithfully, or trivialize it? The background to anti-semitism, use of religious imagery in propaganda films, and what counts as "success" or "failure" in cinematic representations are discussed.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Special Topics
data.description: One or more special courses will be offered at different times. Consult the Department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Canada and the Holocaust
data.description: An analysis of the response to the Holocaust, from 1933 to 1945, and the legacy of the event since the war in Canadian society.

data.subject: JS
data.title: Intermediate Classical Hebrew
data.description: Reading and grammatical analysis of selected passages from the Hebrew Bible.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors, but not both.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Ancient Semitic Texts and Inscriptions
data.description: Reading and analysis of Iron Age inscriptions and ostraca in Hebrew or closely related Canaanite dialects, including the Siloam and Mesha inscriptions and the Lachish letters, plus a selection from the Dead Sea Scrolls.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors, but not both. Taught at Laurier as HB 202.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Jews in the New World
data.description: Push and pull factors led Jews from Europe to the so-called New World (Canada, the United States, South America, the Caribbean) as well as South Africa and Australia. The mass movement of migrants leaving 19th century Europe dramatically transformed world Jewry. This course explores the experiences of various national Jewish communities, the variety of new world Jewries, and the relationship between modern states and their religious and ethnic minorities.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Moses Maimonides: Life and Thought
data.description: This course examines the life and thought of Moses Maimonides, the most important thinker in Jewish history. It explores his contributions to philosophy, law, biblical interpretation and his attempt to reconcile religion and science.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: The Bible (Old Testament) and Archaeology
data.description: This course examines the Bible in relation to the archaeology and material culture of the Ancient Near East. It will explore how archaeological discoveries contribute to our understanding of the events, personalities and narratives of the Hebrew Bible.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B or Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Jewish Contributions to Political Thought
data.description: This course examines Jewish communal organization and contributions to political thought. Issues discussed include the nature of legitimate authority in conditions of Jewish diaspora, the intellectual and political foundations for governance in the Jewish tradition from the time of the Exodus to the establishment of the modern state of Israel.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills the Area 1B requirement for RS majors.]

data.subject: JS
data.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
data.description: One or more special courses will be offered at different times. Consult the Department for current offerings.

data.subject: JS
data.title: Special Topics in Jewish Studies

data.subject: JS
data.title: Jews and Jewishness
data.description: This course examines the central elements that make up contemporary Jewish identity/identities, traditional and otherwise, with particular focus on the North American Jewish experience and the nature of Jewish modernity. It explores historical, literary, religious, and social issues that have contributed to the formation of these identities.
